author: timbeiko
content:
----------

ACD updates for folks who couldn't make it:

1. We're leaving Baikal up until at least the testnet forks so that people can use it to interact with 1559 and other London EIPs. It would be great to send transactions on it which test the various EIPs, and also which raise/lower the base fee on the network, <@!574864862338088960> had built a tool to spam a network with transaction, which should work here: https://github.com/ConsenSys/tommygun-eth 

2. We agreed to use EIP-3554 rather than 3238 for the difficulty bomb pushback and to re-run the numbers ~two months from now to make sure we are still on track. I will follow up on that right after the July fork. 

3. For the JSON RPC naming, we agreed to go with the terms from the spec, namely `baseFeePerGas`, `maxPriorityFeePerGas`, &  `maxFeePerGas`

4. For London timing, we agreed to keep the July 14th mainnet date as a target, but there was some concern that the schedule is tight. We don't want to commit to the block number on mainnet until the first testnet forks successfully, but for testnets, we'll use the following block numbers:  Ropsten: `10399301` (June 9, 2021), Goerli:  `4979794` (June 16, 2021), Rinkeby: `8813188` (June 23, 2021). I've added them to the London spec.

author: timbeiko
content:
TBF, we tried resolving the JSON RPC stuff async all week without success. 

Re: the diff bomb, I think we had pretty strong agreement about it, but I'm very cautious about taking these decisions outside of ACD. IMO I think it's important for these decisions to be formally made on the call. I think it's valuable to try and get folks on the same page prior to the call so we do it efficiently, but I'd be very uncomfortable about not using the call as a place where people can voice disagreements if they have them.

author: timbeiko
content: But look, I agree that there isn't great overlap between what is discussed on ACD and what takes up most of client devs' time. That was my biggest realization when I actually started working on a client. For the past few months, we've had a ton of stuff to discuss about the hard forks, but now that we will have less, we can absolutely use the forum to go over things that are important to devs but don't usually get discussed.
